nodes.text: Conditional convergence hypothesis: a country's subsequent per capita GDP growth rate is determined jointly by initial human capital and initial per capita GDP so that poor countries catch up only when human capital is high relative to their income
Initial human capital (proxied by 1960 school-enrollment rates) is positively related to subsequent per capita GDP growth, holding other variables constant
Initial level of real per capita GDP (1960) is negatively related to subsequent per capita GDP growth when human-capital proxies are held constant (evidence of conditional convergence)
Higher initial human capital is associated with lower fertility and higher physical-investment-to-GDP ratios, linking human capital to growth via fertility and investment channels
Ratio of government consumption to GDP is negatively associated with per capita growth and private investment, consistent with government consumption creating distortions that lower saving and growth
Quantity of public investment shows little systematic positive relation to per capita growth once total investment or private investment is controlled for
Political instability (revolutions, coups, assassinations) is negatively related to investment and growth, plausibly via adverse effects on property rights
Price distortions proxied by deviations in purchasing-power-parity for investment deflators (magnitude of PPP deviation) are negatively related to growth and investment

Method: cross-sectional regressions for 98 countries over 1960-1985 using Summers-Heston and other data; heteroskedasticity-robust standard errors (White) and alternative weightings and specifications
Result: regression 1 coefficient on GDP60 is -0.0075 (s.e. 0.0012); a $1,000 higher initial GDP reduces annual per capita growth by 0.75 percentage points, conditional on other regressors
Result: regression 1 coefficients on SEC60 and PRIM60 are positive and significant (t-values ~3.8 and 4.4); partial correlation of human-capital proxy with growth is about 0.73

Evidence: partial correlations and fitted regressions show strong negative partial correlation between growth and GDP60 (partial r = -0.74) and strong positive partial correlation between growth and school-enrollment measures (partial r = 0.73); figures and multiple regressions support these patterns

Result for fertility: initial school-enrollment rates are significantly negatively associated with net fertility (FERTNET), while GDP60 is insignificant for fertility once human-capital variables are included

Result for investment: initial human-capital proxies are significantly positively associated with private and total investment ratios; GDP60 has a negative partial association with private investment consistent with convergence mechanisms

Evidence on interactions: including investment ratio and net fertility in growth regressions leaves GDP60 negative and significant, while the impact of school-enrollment on growth is reducedâ€”part of schooling effect works through higher investment and lower fertility; residuals of growth and investment are positively correlated and growth and fertility residuals negatively correlated

Conclusion and limitation: results support conditional convergence and highlight channels (human capital, investment, fertility, government consumption, political instability, price distortions), but substantial unexplained weak growth remains for sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America indicating omitted factors or imperfect human-capital proxies
